leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,545] s 59 The hearsay rule — exclusion of hearsay evidence

leg:heading.title: The hearsay rule — exclusion of hearsay evidence

p.text: Evidence of a previous representation made by a person is not admissible to prove the existence of a fact that it can reasonably be supposed that the person intended to assert by the representation.
[subs (1) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[16], effective 1 January 2009]
Such a fact is in this Part referred to as an asserted fact.

For the purposes of determining under subsection (1) whether it can reasonably be supposed that the person intended to assert a particular fact by the representation, the court may have regard to the circumstances in which the representation was made.
Subsection (2A) was inserted as a response to the decision of the Supreme Court of NSW in R v Hannes (2000) 158 FLR 359 .
[subs (2A) insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[17], effective 1 January 2009]

Subsection (1) does not apply to evidence of a representation contained in a certificate or other document given or made under regulations made under an Act other than this Act to the extent to which the regulations provide that the certificate or other document has evidentiary effect.
[subs (3) insrt Act No 53 of 2000 Sch 1]
Specific exceptions to the hearsay rule are as follows:
first-hand hearsay:
character of and expert opinion about accused persons ( sections 110 and 111 ).
Other provisions of this Act, or of other laws, may operate as further exceptions.

D is the defendant in a sexual assault trial. W has made a statement to the police that X told W that X had seen D leave a night club with the victim shortly before the sexual assault is alleged to have occurred. Unless an exception to the hearsay rule applies, evidence of what X told W cannot be given at the trial.

P had told W that the handbrake on W's car did not work. Unless an exception to the hearsay rule applies, evidence of that statement cannot be given by P, W or anyone else to prove that the handbrake was defective.

W had bought a video cassette recorder and written down its serial number on a document. Unless an exception to the hearsay rule applies, the document is inadmissible to prove that a video cassette recorder later found in D's possession was the video cassette recorder bought by W.
[s 59 am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[18], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 684
ALRC 38 para 126
ALRC 102 paras 7.4–7.62
This section is known as the “hearsay rule” for the purpose of the Act. Other terms that appear in the section and are defined in the Dictionary are: “previous representation” and “representation”.
Legislation cited in [50,545.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 59(2A).

The hearsay rule does not exclude evidence of out of court statements that are relevant as original evidence. If the fact that a previous (ie, an out of court) statement was made is relevant, then evidence of its making is admissible: Subramaniam v Public Prosecutor [1956] 1 WLR 965 at 970; Mawaz Khan v R [1976] 1 All ER 80; R v Murphy (1985) 4 NSWLR 42 at 60. Evidence of statements made by an interpreter during an out of court conversation is admissible as the statements made by the person whose conversation was being translated: Tsang Chi Ming v Uvanna Pty Ltd (t/as North West Immigration Services) (1996) 140 ALR 273; BC9604541 ; Lee v R (1998) 195 CLR 594; 157 ALR 394; [1998] HCA 60; BC9804987 .

A previous out of court statement is only within the hearsay rule if it is relied on for the purpose of establishing the truth of the facts the person intended to assert: Pollitt v R (1992) 174 CLR 558 at 602; 108 ALR 1; BC9202688 ; Walton v R (1989) 166 CLR 283; 84 ALR 59 ; R v Ratten [1972] AC 378 ; Alexander v R (1981) 145 CLR 395; 34 ALR 289; BC8100066 (evidence of previous identification). That intention may go beyond the actual words used in the previous representation. It will include any fact the person may reasonably have intended to assert having regard to the circumstances in which the representation was made: s 59(2A) . See R v Hannes (2000) 158 FLR 359; 36 ACSR 72; [2000] NSWCCA 503; BC200007407 at [361] per Spigelman CJ.

Prior to the Evidence Act there was uncertainty as to whether implied representations of different kinds fell within the scope of the hearsay rule: see Ligertwood Australian Evidence, 2nd ed, Butterworths, Sydney, 1993, Ch 8: McGinley & Nage, Implied Assertions and the Hearsay Prohibition (1993) 67 ALJ 687; Walton v R (1989) 166 CLR 283 at 302–304; 84 ALR 59 ; Cross on Evidence (Australian Edition) at [31035]–[31070]. However, the definition of the term “representation” in the Dictionary to the Act is quite explicit and includes “an express or implied representation”: see R v Hannes (2000) 158 FLR 359; 36 ACSR 72; [2000] NSWCCA 503; BC200007407 at [348]–[350] per Spigelman CJ. Accordingly, the effect of the hearsay rule (as now defined) is to allow evidence of previous statements that contain factual assertions that can reasonably be supposed to have been intended having regard to the circumstances in which the statement was made. Thus evidence of an out of court statement in which one person addressed another by name may be admissible as evidence of the fact that the person addressed had that name: see R v Ratten [1972] AC 378 ; R v Ryan (1984) 55 ALR 408; 14 A Crim R 97 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,550] s 60 Exception: evidence relevant for a non-hearsay purpose

leg:heading.title: Exception: evidence relevant for a non-hearsay purpose

p.text: The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of a previous representation that is admitted because it is relevant for a purpose other than proof of an asserted fact.
[subs (1) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[19], effective 1 January 2009]
Subsection (2) was inserted as a response to the decision of the High Court of Australia in Lee v The Queen (1998) 195 CLR 594 .
[subs (2) insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[20], effective 1 January 2009]
However, this section does not apply in a criminal proceeding to evidence of an admission.
The admission might still be admissible under section 81 as an exception to the hearsay rule if it is “first-hand” hearsay: see section 82 .
[subs (3) insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[20], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 334, 685
ALRC 38 paras 126, 144–145
ALRC 102 paras 7.63–7.106
Relevant terms defined in the Dictionary are “representation” and “prior representation”.
Legislation cited in [50,550.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 136, s 60(2).

The section contemplates that evidence may be admissible for a limited purpose notwithstanding the hearsay rule — see [50,545.15] above. By stipulating that the hearsay rule does not apply to evidence so admitted, the section permits the evidence to be used to establish the facts asserted.

The effect of the section is to allow admitted evidence to be used for purposes other than those for which it was originally admissible. Furthermore, s 60(2) permits the previous representation to be admissible as probative of an asserted fact irrespective of the author’s personal knowledge of its truth — in this respect overcoming the effect of the decision in Lee v R (1998) 195 CLR 594; 157 ALR 394; [1998] HCA 60; BC9804987 . This position may be appropriate in some instances (eg, some kinds of prior inconsistent statements: ALRC Report No 26 vol 1 para 685). In other instances it will be necessary to consider using the discretion conferred by s 136 to limit the use to which the evidence can be put: see generally the note in [29.5.25] .
Legislation cited in [50,550.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 136, s 60.

Section 60 reverses the common law rule in Ramsay v Watson (1961) 108 CLR 642 at 649; 35 ALJR 301 that statements contained in a history taken by a doctor, and repeated as the basis for the doctor's opinion, had to be admissibly proved to be received as evidence of the facts stated. The hearsay rule does not apply to the evidence of such previous representations and they are admissible: R v Welsh (1996) 90 A Crim R 364 ; Daw v Toyworld (NSW) Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 25; BC200100409 at [70] . But, despite the admissibility of evidence of this kind, it may be appropriate to apply under s 136 for an order to limit the use of the evidence to prevent any risk of the evidence being used unfairly: Daw , above, at [40]; Roach v Page (No 11) [2003] NSWSC 907; BC200305938 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,555] s 61 Exceptions to the hearsay rule dependent on competency

leg:heading.title: Exceptions to the hearsay rule dependent on competency

p.text: This Part does not enable use of a previous representation to prove the existence of an asserted fact if, when the representation was made, the person who made it was not competent to give evidence about the fact because of section 13(1) .
[subs (1) subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[21], effective 1 January 2009]
This section does not apply to a contemporaneous representation made by a person about his or her health, feelings, sensations, intention, knowledge or state of mind.
For the admissibility of such contemporaneous representations, see section 66A .
[subs (2) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[22], effective 1 January 2009]
For the purposes of this section, it is presumed, unless the contrary is proved, that when the representation was made the person who made it was competent to give evidence about the asserted fact.
